articles.title: Compile Course Notes
articles.contents:
Statistical Data Visualization


Home
Notes
☰


  
    
      
        
        
        
      
      
    
    
      
  Home


  Notes

      
  






Compile Course Notes




Run this from the stat436_notes root directory to compile all course
notes.

Clean up previous builds
# Remove any existing HTML files in post directories
unlink(list.files("_posts", pattern = "*.html", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE))

# Clear cache directories
system("find _posts -type d -name '*cache*' -exec rm -rf {} +")
system("find _posts -type d -name '*files*' -exec rm -rf {} +")


Compile individual posts
library(tidyverse)
library(rmarkdown)
library(distill)

# Find all .Rmd files in _posts subdirectories
files <- list.files(path = "_posts", pattern = "*.Rmd", recursive = TRUE, full.names = TRUE)

# Exclude the compile script itself
files <- setdiff(files, c("_posts/compile.Rmd"))

# Render each individual post
cat("Found", length(files), "files to render:\n")
for (i in seq_along(files)) {
  cat("Rendering", i, "of", length(files), ":", files[i], "\n")
  tryCatch({
    render(files[i])
  }, error = function(e) {
    cat("Error rendering", files[i], ":", e$message, "\n")
  })
}


Render the full site
# Now render the complete site
render_site()


Instructions
To use this script:
Make sure you’re in the root directory of your project
Run each chunk manually or knit this document
Check the docs/ directory for the compiled site
The script will: - Clean up any previous builds - Render each
individual course note - Compile the main site with proper
navigation

articles.title: Statistical Data Visualization
articles.contents:
Contents
Background Readings

This website only includes links to the reading and lecture content – the
course assignments, recordings, and discussions are mapped out fully on the
Canvas homepage.
Background Readings
Course notes are listed here. Source code and links to recorded
videos are listed at the top of each set of lecture notes. While the notes are
required reading, the background texts below are not. We have included them here
in case you would like to read more deeply into topics introduced in the class.
Week
Topic
Optional Reading
1 
Marks and Channels
(1) Introduction to Data Science: Chapter 7  (2) Fundamentals of Data Visualization: Chapters 2  (3) Data Humanism
2 
Data Wrangling
(1) R for Data Science: Chapter 12 (2) Fundamentals of Data Visualization: Chapter 5
3 
Faceting and Layout
(1) Fundamentals of Data Visualization: Chapter 21 (2) Introduction to Data Science: Chapter 9.1 - 9.3, 9.7
4 
Interaction I
(1) Mastering Shiny: Chapters 3, 4  (2) Visualization Analysis and Design: Chapter 12.1 - 12.3, 13.1 - 13.3  (3) Up and Down the Ladder of Abstraction
5 
Interaction II
(1) Mastering Shiny: Chapter 7  (2) Crosstalk tutorial
6 
Time Series
Forecasting Principles and Practice: Chapter 2
7 
Geographic Data
Geographic Data in R: Chapter 2
8 
Network Data
(1) Visualization Analysis and Design: Chapter 9  (2) Modern Statistics for Modern Biology: Chapter 10.1 - 10.2
9 
Clustering
(1) Intro to Data Science: Chapter 34 (2) Superheat Vignette (2, 3 & 6)  (3) Cluster Analysis of Genomic Data
10 
Dimensionality Reduction I
(1) Beginner’s Guide to Dimensionality Reduction  (2) PCA and UMAP with tidymodels and #TidyTuesday cocktail recipes  (3) Understanding UMAP
11 
Dimensionality Reduction II
(1) Text mining with R: Chapter 6  (2) Visualizing the structure of RNA-seq expression data using grade of membership models
12 
Model Building
(1) Partial-dependence Profiles  (2) Visualization in Bayesian workflow
13 
Deep Learning Models
(1) Four Experiments in Handwriting with a Neural Network  (2) Visualizing what convnets learn  (3) Agency plus automation: Designing artificial intelligence into interactive systems
14 
Conclusion
(1) 655 Frustrations of Doing Data Visualization  (2) Tukey, Design Thinking, and Better Questions  (3) A Brief History of Data Visualization
